docs.lead_paragraph: The first time I had even a fleeting thought of my own grandchildren came last weekend, as I lobbed most of the contents of my garage into a rented dumpster. (Yep, that's what I asked for on Mother's Day. Best gift ever!) Cracked bike helmets, followed by rain-stiffened mitts, followed by sand-filled boogie boards, followed by bent tennis rackets. As I purged my boys' pasts I didn't look back.

headline.main: Older Moms, Grandparents and Hand-Me-Down Highchairs

docs.abstract: The Pew Research Center confirmed earlier this month what you've probably noticed just by looking around any playground -- older mothers are more common.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Midshipman Jessica Wilcox, who graduates from the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis this month, said she first pictured herself aboard a submarine when she was a ''dreamy young person,'' long before women were allowed to join the nation's nuclear submarine service. Now, she is among the first group of women to be tapped for the elite force, one of the military's last all-male bastions.

headline.main: Quiet Resistance to Women on Subs

docs.abstract: Female midshipmen applaud United States Navy for allowing women to serve on submarines, but many active-duty and retired submariners oppose new policy; privately, many sailors say they believe decision was made for political and not operational reasons; photo (M)

headline.seo: Getting the Pretty Back, Chapter One: Isn’t It Pretty to Think So

docs.snippet: Molly Ringwald writes about the grown-up life in her new book, “Getting the Pretty Back.”

docs.lead_paragraph: Via Eve Tushnet, I see that Maggie Gallagher got there first on the point I made in yesterday's column - namely, that a lot of the differences between "red" and "blue" family structures, as sketched in Naomi Cahn and June Carbone's recent book, are driven by higher abortion rates in liberal states. And it really is striking, when you dig into the data, how much of the blue-state advantage in preventing teen births is made possible by abortion. Rhode Island's teen pregnancy rate is identical to West Virginia's, but West Virginia's teen birth rate is 33 percent higher. California's teen pregnancy rate is higher than Alabama's, but California's teen birth rate is 20 percent lower. Kentucky and Maryland have the same teen pregnancy rates, but Kentucky has almost 60 percent more teenage births. And so on ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Genetic tests that assess a person's risk of getting various diseases are heading to the corner drug store. Pathway Genomics, a start-up company, is expected to announce on Tuesday that it will sell such a test through most of the nation's 7,500 Walgreens stores, Andrew Pollack writes in The New York Times.
